{{Infobox person | name = Romola Garai | image = Romola Garai.jpg | imagesize = 200px | caption = Garai at the 2007 [[Toronto International Film Festival]] | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1982|8|6|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Hong Kong]] | birth_name = Romola Sadie Garai | nationality = [[British nationality law|British]] | occupation = [[Actress]] | yearsactive = 2000âpresent }} '''Romola Sadie Garai''' ({{IPAc-en|icon|Ë|r|É|m|É|l|É|_|Ë|s|eÉª|d|i|_|Ë|É¡|Ã¦|r|i|}};<ref>See: {{cite news|first=Romola|last=Garai|coauthor=Mustafa Khalili|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/video/2009/mar/19/syria-refugees-romola-garai|title='For these refugees, resettlement is the only option'|date=20 March 2009|accessdate=15 November 2009|work=The Guardian|location=London}}</ref> born 6 August 1982) is an English actress. She is known for appearing in the movies ''[[Amazing Grace (2006 film)|Amazing Grace]]'', ''[[Atonement (film)|Atonement]]'', and ''[[Glorious 39]]'', and for appearing in the [[BBC]] adaptation of ''[[Emma (2009 TV serial)|Emma]]''.
==Early life== Garai was born in Hong Kong to British parents.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://youtube.com/watch?v=rVW7A5h67g4|title=Romola Garai Interview with ''Premiere France''|publisher=Premiere France|author=|date=|accessdate=2007-05-18}}</ref><ref name="uni"/> Her mother, Janet A. (nÃ©e Brown), worked as a journalist, and her father, Adrian E. R. Garai, is a banker.<ref name="ref091">{{cite news|last=|first=|coauthors=|title=Petticoat tales |publisher=Herald Scotland|date=2007-03-17|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/petticoat-tales-1.835133|accessdate=2009-10-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/8586679/Romola-Garai-interview-feminism-and-the-1950s.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | title=Romola Garai interview: feminism and the 1950s | date=19 July 2011}}</ref> Her first name is the female version of [[Romulus and Remus|Romulus]], one of the founders of [[Rome]].<ref name="Independent Oct 2004">{{cite news|last=McLean|first=Craig|title=Romola Garai: Dancing Queen|pages=| work=The Independent| date= 10 October 2004|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/features/romola-garai-dancing-queen-542935.html|accessdate=2009-10-01|location=London}}</ref> Garai's great-grandfather, Bernhard "Bert" Garai, a [[Hungarian Jews|Hungarian Jewish]] immigrant, founded the Keystone Press Agency, a photographic agency and archive, in London in the early twentieth century.<ref>{{cite web|first=Tim|last=Lewis|url=http://www.romola-garai.com/articles/2004/2004_esquire_nov.html|title=Fifteen Stupid Questions for Romola Garai|work=British Esquire|date=November 2004|accessdate=5 December 2009}}</ref><ref name="bio2">{{cite news|first=Nick|last=Duerden| url=http://news.independent.co.uk/people/profiles/article2360312.ece|title=Romola Garai: A woman on the edge of stardom|work=The Independent | date=15 March 2007| accessdate=2007-05-18|location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.keystonepressagency.com/us/about.html|title=Keystone Press Agency, Ltd.|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/63JtfbsmN|archivedate=19 November 2011|deadurl=no}}</ref>
Garai is the third of four siblings.<ref name="ref1122">{{cite news|last=Molony|first=Julia|title=Romola gets the balance right|work=The Independent|date=2009-11-22|url=http://www.independent.ie/entertainment/film-cinema/romola-gets-the-balance-right-1950692.html|accessdate=2009-11-22}}</ref> She moved to [[Singapore]] at five, before her family returned to [[Wiltshire]] in [[England]] when she was eight. She attended an independent boarding school, [[Stonar School]] in Wiltshire, and later moved at sixteen to [[London]] to attend the [[City of London School for Girls]], where she completed her A-levels. She was fond of drama and appeared in school plays, and also with the [[National Youth Theatre]] up until the age of eighteen, where she was spotted by an agent who signed her to play the younger version of Dame [[Judi Dench]]'s character in the [[BBC Films]]/[[HBO]] co-production for television, ''[[The Last of the Blonde Bombshells]]''.<ref name="uni"/>
After A-levels, she studied English Literature at [[Queen Mary, University of London]], before transferring and graduating with a first class degree from the [[Open University]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/passedfailed-an-education-in-the-life-of-the-actor-romola-garai-1926578.html|work=The Independent|location=London|title=Passed/Failed: An education in the life of the actor Romola Garai|date=25 March 2010|accessdate=22 May 2010}}</ref> She originally intended only to focus on her studies but later began acting full time during the summer holiday.<ref name="uni">{{cite web|url=http://www.indielondon.co.uk/film/capture_the_castle_gariaQ&A.html|title=I Capture The Castle - Romola Garai Q&A|publisher=Indie London|author=Jack Foley|year=2003|accessdate=2007-05-18}}</ref> She is a former [[model (person)|model]].<ref name="Independent Oct 2004" />
==Acting career== Garai's first professional acting role was in the 2000 BBC-[[HBO]] TV film ''[[The Last of the Blonde Bombshells]]'',<ref name="Independent Nov 2009">{{cite news|first=Nina|last=Lakhani|title=Romola Garai: An actor's life for me â at least for now|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/romola-garai-an-actors-life-for-me-ndash-at-least-for-now-1820967.html|work=The Independent|date=15 November 2009|accessdate=15 November 2009|location=London}}</ref> where she played [[Judi Dench]]'s character as young. She then landed a part in the BBC 26-part television series ''[[Attachments (TV series)|Attachments]]'' (2000â2002).<ref name="Independent Nov 2009" /> It was this production that prompted her to make the decision to stop her education and concentrate solely on her acting career.<ref name="uni"/>
Garai's first major film role was in 2002's ''[[Nicholas Nickleby (2002 film)|Nicholas Nickleby]]''.<ref name="Independent Nov 2009" /> She played Kate Nickleby, a supporting role, in the well-reviewed film. The entire cast was widely recognized for their work and were awarded Best Ensemble by the [[National Board of Review]]. In 2003's ''[[I Capture the Castle (film)|I Capture the Castle]]'', she played 17-year-old Cassandra Mortmain. She received glowing praise for her work. Her performance earned her a nomination for a Most Promising Newcomer award from the British Independent Film Awards.<ref name="BIFA">{{cite web|url=http://www.bifa.org.uk|title=Romola Garai: BIFA Nominations|publisher=The British Independent Film Awards|accessdate=5 December 2009}}</ref>
''[[Dirty Dancing: Havana Nights]]'' (2004) was Garai's biggest critical flop to date. Her performance received mixed reviews â many critics felt let down after her previous impressive turns.{{Citation needed|date=October 2009}} Later that same year ''[[Vanity Fair (2004 film)|Vanity Fair]]'' was released. In ''Vanity Fair'', she played Amelia Sedley. Co-starring [[:Reese Witherspoon]], [[:Jim Broadbent]], and [[:James Purefoy]], the movie was based on the 19th century novel by [[:William Makepeace Thackeray]] and it was directed by [[:Mira Nair]]. The movie received mixed reviews.
In 2005, Garai received another BIFA nomination, this time for their Best Supporting Actress award, for her performance as Siobhan in the independent film ''[[Inside I'm Dancing]]''.<ref name="BIFA" /> Her portrayal earned her the British Supporting Actress of the Year award from the [[London Film Critics Circle]]. Also in 2005, she starred in a two-part drama made for television, entitled ''[[The Incredible Journey of Mary Bryant]]''. While critics hailed it as "pleasingly old-fashioned adventure," it was her performance that won the most admiration and earn her two nominations: Best Lead Actress in Television from the [[Australian Film Institute]] and Most Outstanding Actress in a Drama Series from the [[Logie Awards]]. As ''The Observer'' noted: ''"As for the tireless Garai, she once again demonstrated an instinctive understanding of the vital difference between overperforming and overacting."'' {{Citation needed|date=September 2010}}
She can be seen in [[Kenneth Branagh]]'s [[film adaptation]] of William Shakespeare's ''[[As You Like It]]'' (2006), as Celia. The film was released in some European cinemas before being broadcast in 2007 on HBO cable television in the U.S. In 2009, it opened in theatres in [[Mexico]].<ref>{{cite web|title=As You Like It (2006) - Release dates|url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0450972/releaseinfo|publisher=IMDb|accessdate=15 November 2009}}</ref>
In 2007, Garai starred as Angel Deverell in [[FranÃ§ois Ozon]]'s ''[[Angel (2007 film)|Angel]]''. ''The Independent'' named her one of the actresses of the year for her performance in ''Angel''.<ref>{{cite news|first=Jonathan|last=Romney|title=Film in 2008: Who was top of the heap? A talking tin can|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/reviews/film-in-2008-who-was-top-of-the-heap-a-talking-tin-can-1213404.html|work=The Independent|date=28 December 2008|accessdate=15 November 2009|location=London}}</ref> Garai was also nominated for the ''Prix Lumiere'' award<ref>{{cite news|first=David|last=Hayhurst|title=French quartet vie for Prix Lumieres|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117977889.html?categoryid=13&cs=1|work=Variety|date=18 December 2007|accessdate=15 November 2009}}</ref> (the French equivalent of the Golden Globes), as Best Female Newcomer for ''Angel'', making her the first British actress to be nominated for a ''Prix Lumiere''.
In 2007, she also starred in the Oscar-nominated movie ''[[Atonement (film)|Atonement]]'' as the teenaged Briony Tallis. Co-starring [[:Keira Knightley]], [[:James McAvoy]], [[:Vanessa Redgrave]], and [[:Brenda Blethyn]], the movie went on to receive seven Academy Award nominations, including Best Picture. Garai earned a Best Actress nomination from the [[Evening Standard British Film Awards]] for her performance.<ref>{{cite news|title=Keira Knightley - Atonement leads Evening Standard British Film Awards|url=http://www.contactmusic.com/news.nsf/article/atonement%20leads%20evening%20standard%20british%20film%20awards_1056970|publisher=Contactmusic.com|date=21 January 2008|accessdate=15 November 2009|quote=Knightley goes up against her co-star Romola Garai for the Best Actress award...}}</ref> She also appeared in two [[Royal Shakespeare Company]] productions: as [[Cordelia]] in ''[[King Lear]]'' and as Nina in ''[[The Seagull]]'', starring alongside [[Ian McKellen]], [[Frances Barber]], [[Sylvester McCoy]], [[Jonathan Hyde]], and [[William Gaunt]]. The run, which toured the world, went into residence in the [[New London Theatre]] where it ended mid-January 2008. She received rave reviews, especially as ''Nina'' in ''The Seagull,'' ''The Independent'' calling her a "woman on the edge of stardom,"<ref>{{cite news|first=Nick|last=Duerden|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/romola-garai-a-woman-on-the-edge-of-stardom-440326.html|title=Romola Garai: A woman on the edge of stardom|work=The Independent|date=15 March 2007|accessdate=15 November 2009|location=London}}</ref> and ''This Is London'' calling her "superlative", and stating that the play was "distinguished by the illuminating, psychological insights of Miss Garai's performance."<ref>{{cite news|first=Nicholas|last=de Jongh|url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/theatre/show-23377371-details/The%20Seagull/showReview.do?reviewId=23423456|title=The fall of a high-flying bird |work=London Evening Standard|date=28 November 2007|accessdate=15 november 2009}}</ref> She reprised her role as Cordelia in a televised version of ''[[King Lear (2008 TV film)|King Lear]]''.
In 2008. she appeared in the feature film ''[[The Other Man (film)|The Other Man]]'' alongside [[Liam Neeson]], [[Laura Linney]], and [[Antonio Banderas]]. Garai next starred in Stephen Poliakoff's World War II thriller ''[[Glorious 39]]'', alongside [[Julie Christie]], [[Jenny Agutter]], [[Bill Nighy]], [[Christopher Lee]], and [[Eddie Redmayne]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Stephen|last=Poliakoff|title=Romola Garai stars in Glorious 39|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/film/article6912742.ece|work=The Times|date=15 November 2009|accessdate=15 November 2009|location=London}}</ref> The movie had its world premiere at the Toronto Film Festival.<ref>{{cite news|first=Jennie|last=Punter|title=Toronto adds to Special Presentations|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118006395.html?categoryid=13&cs=1|work=Variety|date=23 July 2009|accessdate=15 November 2009}}</ref>
In 2009, she played the title role in a television adaptation of [[Jane Austen]]'s ''[[Emma (2009 TV serial)|Emma]]'', a four-hour miniseries that premiered on BBC One in October 2009, co-starring [[Jonny Lee Miller]] and [[Michael Gambon|Sir Michael Gambon]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Anita|last=Singh|title=Romola Garai to play Emma in BBC's latest Jane Austen adaptation|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/culturenews/5100713/Romola-Garai-to-play-Emma-in-BBCs-latest-Jane-Austen-adaptation.html|work=The Telegraph|date=4 April 2009|accessdate=15 November 2009|location=London}}</ref> Garai was nominated for a [[Golden Globe]] for her performance. ''Emma'' then appeared on American television as part of [[PBS]]' [[Masterpiece Classic]] anthology series, airing in most U.S. markets over three consecutive Sunday evenings during January and February 2010. American actress [[Laura Linney]], who had co-starred with Garai in ''The Other Man'', was the presenter for ''Masterpiece Classic'' during the anthology's "season" (US)/"series" (UK) at the time, and she introduced each of the three installments that featured her former co-star.
She was attached to play American First Lady [[Jacqueline Kennedy]] in ''Flying Into Love'';<ref>{{cite web |title= Flying into Love|url=http://www.hollywood.com/movie/Flying_into_Love/4574674|publisher=Hollywood.com |accessdate=15 November 2009}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> she will also appear in [[Hettie MacDonald]]'s feature ''Nova Scotia'', in which she plays a character called Lucy Hay;<ref>{{cite web|title=Nova Scotia|url=http://www.bardentertainments.co.uk/Site/Nova_Scotia.html|publisher=Bard Entertainments|accessdate=15 November 2009}}</ref> and also in director Gareth Bryn's ''Driven'', which is written by Catrin Clarke.<ref>{{cite news|first=Karen|last=Price|title=Wales is the new star of the movies|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/showbiz-and-lifestyle/2009/03/28/wales-is-the-new-star-of-the-movies-91466-23250703|work=WalesOnline |date=28 March 2009|accessdate=5 December 2009|quote=An additional Â£150,000 has been awarded by the Film Agency for Wales to Rondo Media for the feature film Driven by writer Catrin Clarke... Directed by Gareth Bryn, it will feature Romola Garai, who was in Atonement, in the lead role of Beth.}}</ref> Garai has also signed to play the female lead in ''I Was Bono's DoppelgÃ¤nger'', alongside Charlie Cox and another former co-star, Bill Nighy.<ref>{{cite news|first=Audrey|last=Ward|title=Salt tempts buyers with I Was Bono's Doppelganger|url=http://www.screendaily.com/news/production/uk-ireland/salt-tempts-buyers-with-i-was-bonos-doppelganger/5001114.article|work=Screen Daily|date=14 May 2009|accessdate=15 November 2009}}</ref> Filming was set to begin in August 2009.
In 2009, ''The Sunday Times Magazine'' named her as one of Britain's Rising Stars<ref>{{cite news|title=Britain's got talent|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/film/article5579683.ece|work=The Sunday Times|date=25 January 2009|accessdate=15 November 2009|location=London|first=Fiona|last=Hamilton}}</ref> alongside Matthew Goode, Andrea Riseborough, Hugh Dancy, Eddie Redmayne and others. In January of that year she travelled to the Syrian-Iraqi border to make a short film titled ''No Man's Land'' for the [[UNHCR]], highlighting the plight of 800 Palestinian refugees living in the Al-Tanaf refugee camp. Of her visit to the refugee camps Garai states, "My trip to a refugee camp in Syria destroyed any hope that the horrors of Iraq might end, or that we are doing enough to help its victims."<ref name="Guardian Mar 2009">{{cite news|first=Romola|last=Garai|title=No man's land|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2009/mar/19/iraq-syria-refugees|work=The Guardian|date=20 March 2009|accessdate=15 November 2009|location=London}}</ref> Garai has been hailed by her ''Glorious 39'' director Stephen Poliakoff as "the next Kate Winslet" and someone who will "dominate British cinema" in the future.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/showbiz-and-lifestyle/2009/11/24/poliakoff-returns-to-the-big-screen-91466-25240597|title=Poliakoff returns to the big screen|work=WalesOnline|date=24 November 2009|accessdate=5 December 2009}}</ref>
In 2011, Garai starred in the four-part BBC drama ''[[The Crimson Petal and the White (TV miniseries)|The Crimson Petal and the White]]'' based on [[The Crimson Petal and the White|the novel]] by [[Michel Faber]]. She has commented on her racy part of Sugar, a 19th century mistress, that "standing in pants and suspenders, waiting for someone to call action, is pretty cringy ... By the end everyone on the set was like, 'Please just put it away.'"<ref>Interview with Deborah Feldman, ''Tatler'', July 2011</ref> In 2011 she played Bel Rowley in the TV drama ''[[The Hour (drama series)|The Hour]]'' leading with [[Dominic West]] and [[Ben Whishaw]], and the stage play ''[[The Village Bike]]'' at the Royal Court.
Garai has signed on to star alongside actress [[Anne Hathaway (actress)|Anne Hathaway]] and [[Jim Sturgess]] in [[Lone Scherfig]]'s ''[[One Day (film)|One Day]]''.<ref>http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=66281</ref> She will also play the part of a junkie single mother in the independent British film ''Junkhearts'' with [[Eddie Marsan]] and [[Tom Sturridge]],.<ref>[http://www.darkhorizons.com/news/17390 ''Junkhearts'']</ref>
==Personal life== Garai's great-grandfather emigrated from [[Budapest]] to New York in the 1910s with his English-born wife, then moved to London, where he founded the Keystone Press Agency.<ref>{{cite news|first=Aidan|last=Smith|title=Interview: Romola Garai, actress|url=http://www.scotsman.com/features/Interview-Romola-Garai-actress.5849358.jp|work=Scotsman.com|date=23 November 2009|accessdate=5 December 2009}}</ref><ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=2ZI5AQAAIAAJ&q=%22BERNHARD+GARAI%22&dq=%22BERNHARD+GARAI%22&hl=en]</ref> Most of her Hungarian-Jewish relatives were killed in the Holocaust. Garai admits she has "not yet" been to Hungary and feels modern, cosmopolitan, and British.<ref name="Independent Nov 2009" /> She lives in London and in 2009 finished her degree in English Literature with the [[Open University]].<ref>{{cite news|first=John|last=Preston|title=Romola Garai: on a roll|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/3558305/Romola-Garai-on-a-roll.html|work=Telegraph|date=10 August 2008|accessdate=15 November 2009|location=London}}</ref>
Garai guards her private life, saying, ''"It's too simplistic to say that people start to believe what's written about them. But what happens is that you become a certain way to please people, to be liked, to be what's expected of you, to change yourself so that you become the best possible version of yourself for people who don't know you. And I think that's a terrible, pernicious thing."''<ref name="The Age Nov 2007">{{cite news|first=Philippa|last=Hawker|title=Where angels fear not|url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/film/where-angels-fear-not/2007/11/16/1194766927209.html|work=The Age|date=17 November 2007|accessdate=15 November 2009|location=Melbourne}}</ref> She adds, ''"In a way, I'd rather go into an interview and be disliked, and have unpleasant things written about me, than to have a wonderful, glowing article written that is in no way a reflection of who I am."''<ref name="The Age Nov 2007"/>
Garai enjoys traveling and cooking in her spare time, calling it 'therapeutic'<ref name="Interview Mar 2004">{{cite news|first=Scott Lyle|last=Cohen|title=Romola Garai: her personal history reads like a Jane Austen novel. Now she's taking her adventures to Hollywood|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1285/is_2_34/ai_113764214/?tag=content;col1|work=Interview|date=March 2004|accessdate=15 November 2009}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> in many ways. She has visited Hong Kong, Malaysia, Italy, Austria, Morocco, and Switzerland, and the United States, "To be the outsider for a period of time changes you for the better. It shakes up your comfort level. You have to really make an effort to enter into other people's culture and psychology and language, which the British are very bad at doing."<ref name="Interview Mar 2004"/>
